title: Shea spent 30 years serving her country. Musk said 'you're fired'
text:
In her 28 years working for the federal government, Shea Giagnorio provided daycare for the children of US soldiers, training for employees and oversight for safety net programs.

Public service took her from Germany to Alaska to Kansas City, Missouri, where she moved last year for a long-sought promotion.

But when she reported to a downtown federal building for work one day last month, her access card did not work. After a co-worker let her into the building, she checked her email: her entire office had been let go in the latest mass firing ordered by President Donald Trump’s administration .

Shea Giagnorio packs belongings in her apartment days after getting fired from her job with the Administration for Children and Families. (AP)

The 46-year-old single mum has cancelled her apartment lease, is selling her new furniture and may have to pull her daughter out of college. She wonders what will happen to the at-risk populations her team helped serve at the Administration for Children and Families, a part of the US Department of Health and Human Services.

“Not only me, but all these peoples’ lives are turned upside down,” Giagnorio said.

The impact of the cuts by Trump appointees and Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency can be found everywhere in the Kansas City metropolitan area, which has long been a major hub for federal agencies about 1600km away from Washington, DC.

Money once promised to the region for public health, environmental, diversity, food aid and an array of other programs has been axed, and thousands of local jobs are in jeopardy.

With nearly 30,000 workers, the federal government is the largest employer in the region. One longtime Kansas City economic researcher said the region could lose 6000 good-paying federal jobs, which in turn would wipe out thousands of others in service industries.

An IRS worker said thousands of her co-workers fear they will lose their jobs, even as they put in overtime processing tax refunds in a building so crowded that they struggle to find desks. Under pressure, hundreds more agreed this past week to retire early or take a buyout.

“It’s a kick in the stomach to people that are doing everything they can to meet what’s required of them,” said Shannon Ellis, a longtime IRS customer service representative and president of the union representing local workers.

By Thursday, at least 238 Kansas City workers had taken the buyout offers and were expected to leave the agency in coming weeks. Ellis noted many of those same workers had been told they were essential and required to work overtime during tax season, some seven days per week.

Giagnorio is now on the job hunt after serving almost three decades for the US federal government. (AP)

A US Department of Agriculture grant revocation disrupted a historically black neighbourhood’s plan to expand its program growing fresh produce in a food desert. A nearby pantry reduced its monthly grocery allotment for those in need after federal cuts left food banks shorthanded.

Urban farmer Rosie Warren grew about a ton of fruits and vegetables last year in community gardens to help feed the Ivanhoe neighbourhood, where many black families were concentrated under housing segregation policies of much of the 20th century.

Warren harvested greens, potatoes and watermelons as part of an effort to address food insecurity and health concerns in a neighborhood challenged by blight, crime and poverty. She was ecstatic last fall when the USDA awarded the neighbourhood council a three-year, $US130,000 ($20grant to expand the gardens and farmers’ market serving the area.

In February, the council received a notice terminating the grant. The USDA had determined the award “no longer effectuates agency priorities regarding diversity, equity, and inclusion programs and activities.”

“What do you do if you don’t support providing access to food to people who don’t have it? Wouldn’t this make your job easier?” she said. “I think it’s absurd. It doesn’t make any sense.”

The withdrawal of federal funding for new lab equipment and vaccines means the city may be less prepared for the next pandemic.

Elon Musk has pushed the Trump administration to swing the axe on the public service. (AP)

The Kansas City Health Department’s laboratory is badly in need of an upgrade, with equipment dating to when the building opened in the 1990s.

One basement space is water damaged and rarely used. Another has equipment that is so inadequate that the city has to ship samples to a state laboratory 150 miles away, causing inefficiencies, agonizing waits for results and delayed response times.

But the funding for lab upgrades was abruptly eliminated last month as part of the Trump administration’s $US11.4 billion cancellation of federal grants to states for public health.

An HHS spokesperson said the agency's downsizing, including cutting jobs and consolidating divisions, would save money and make the organisation more efficient. As for the $US11.4 billion in grant funding cuts, the spokesperson said, “HHS will no longer waste billions of taxpayer dollars responding to a nonexistent pandemic that Americans moved on from years ago.”

The IRS has offered a similar rationale for its downsizing, saying it is making process improvements that will ultimately more efficiently serve the public.

Musk said last year that Trump’s budget cuts would cause a “temporary hardship” that would soon put the economy on stronger footing.

One local economic researcher said it remained unclear just how deep that hardship would be in Kansas City, including whether it would just slow growth or cause population losses.

“It's a big burden that’s being placed on a narrow group of people,” said Frank Lenk, director of the Office of Economic Development at the Mid-America Regional Council, a non-profit of city and county governments in the Kansas City region. “It will definitely take some of the steam out of the local economy."

Trump has credited DOGE with helping end “the flagrant waste of taxpayer dollars,” saving billions to help improve the nation’s finances.

title: Men marry their 'seventh' wife in 3000-people mass wedding
text:
1 of 9 Attribution: AP

A Pentecostal church in South Africa celebrated Easter Sunday with mass wedding ceremonies for about 3000 people, with many of them entering into polygamous marriages.

Pictured are groomsmen queuing to collect their partner's flower bouquet inside a marquee at the International Pentecost Holiness Church in Heidelberg, east of Johannesburg, South Africa.

title: Man slips off Queensland cliff in first date disaster
text:
A man is recovering in hospital following a death-defying first date in the Glasshouse Mountains in Queensland .

The climber plunged 30 metres, sparking a major emergency rescue , which all unfolded in front of the girl he was trying to win over.

Scenes that should have resembled a rom-com quickly turned into an action film, after the first date took an unlikely turn on the Sunshine Coast.

READ MORE: Windscreen crashes on dad as boat capsizes during powerful swell

A man is recovering in hospital following a death-defying first date in the Glasshouse Mountains. (9News)

The pair set off for a romantic Easter weekend hike yesterday, free-climbing the rock face, until the 27-year-old man slipped, falling 30 metres down Mt Beerwah.

"Yeah, quite a significant fall and mechanics of injury are high," Queensland Fire Department's Luke Champman told 9News.

It isn't what falling head over heels is supposed to look like, with his fall leading to a multi-agency response, with emergency crews scaling cliffs with gear in hand.

"They were able to package the patient in conjunction with QAS (Queensland Ambulance Services) and move him to a location that was suitable to be winched/extricated by a helicopter," Champman said.

The hiker was found unresponsive, suffering severe head and pelvic injuries.

"He's really lucky," Jeff Bradfield from Queensland Ambulance Services told 9News.

The climber plunged 30 metres, sparking a major emergency rescue, which all unfolded in front of the girl he was trying to win over. (9News)

His date lent a hand to first responders, as a rescue helicopter flew in and winched him to safety. (9News)

A group of army reserves on a training walk witnessed the man fall, rushing to the bottom of the cliff to help.

"They were able to render first aid pretty much immediately to the casualties and provide us good location details," Champman said.

His date lent a hand to first responders, as a rescue helicopter flew in and winched him to safety.

She's now by his side at the Royal Brisbane and Women's Hospital, where her date is in a stable condition, receiving treatment for his injuries - and, perhaps, a bruised ego.

title: Cruise ships to return to SA's Copper Coast after seven-year hiatus
text:
There are high hopes cruise ships will return to South Australia's Copper Coast on the Yorke Peninsula after a seven-year hiatus.

The first time a cruise ship docked at Wallaroo Jetty was in 2019. The last time was in mid-2020, thanks to the coronavirus pandemic.

The South Australian Tourism Commission (SATC) has announced a single cruise ship will return to Wallaroo on March 20, 2027.

The "luxury" cruise ship Seabourn Quest will carry about 458 guests and dock at Wallaroo Jetty for a single-day stopover as part of its broader South Australian itinerary, which includes Adelaide, Kangaroo Island and Port Lincoln.

Wallaroo Holiday Park on SA's Copper Coast. (Supplied: Wallaroo Holiday Park)

Tempered optimism for businesses

For Wallaroo's businesses, the announcement is welcome — but they are eager to hear firm details.

Cafe owner Keegan Thirlway said he was realistic about what the news meant.

The Shores Eatery could be set to benefit from a cruise ship visit. (ABC North and West: Declan Durrant)

"It's pretty ideal — I'm the first one they're going to see," Mr Thirlway said.

"[But] we're already a pretty consistently busy sort of place as it is.

"There might not be scope to get a lot of people through. It depends on the day."

A long wait for a slice of the pie

The popular holiday town, home to about 4,000 people, feted the arrival of cruise ships in 2019, with its passengers providing a much-welcome economic injection.

While the local council hailed it as the start of an exciting new tourism industry, the boost was short-lived.

The SA government said the 2023–24 cruise season was the state's most successful ever.

It injected a record $227 million into the economy, according to a report commissioned by Cruise Lines International Association and the Australian Cruise Association.

Copper Coast Council chief executive officer Dylan Strong said the Copper Coast was "keen to get their slice of that".

Dylan Strong says cruise ships could put Wallaroo on the map. (ABC Riverland: Matt Stephens)

In a report seen by the ABC, compiled by Regional Development Australia, Seabourn Quest's stopover in Wallaroo in 2027 is forecast to inject $96,638 into the Yorke and Mid North economy.

"We've got the economic impact, but from a high-level perspective it does put and keep Wallaroo, the Copper Coast and indeed the Yorke Peninsula on the map," Mr Strong said.

Not all smooth sailing

State Tourism Minister Zoe Bettison said it was a "day to celebrate" but there were still challenges on the horizon.

Australian travel brand P&O Cruises will cease sailing in March, 2025.

It announced it would integrate into the Carnival Cruise Line brand in June last year.

Many of P&O's Explorer Cruises — vessels which travelled to regional ports — were summarily scrapped.

"That was a big decision for P&O, and that will be impactful to us here [in SA] — but we also know there are opportunities that present," Ms Bettison said.

"I'm going to be really up-front: there is going to be some challenges in the next two cruise seasons.

"But then we see these great opportunities of getting more diverse types of cruise ships."

title: Live: Galvin hits the field amid contract and bullying saga
text:
Lachlan Galvin will play in the NSW Cup on Easter Monday in his first match since being dropped from the Wests Tigers first-grade side.

Galvin's plans to depart the Tigers at the end of 2026 have been the biggest story in the sport over the past week, with the teenager's camp accusing the club of bullying.

He will play for Wests Magpies at Lidcombe Oval at 12pm before the first-grade side takes on Parramatta at Western Sydney Stadium at 4pm.

Follow the live blog below, keep up to date with all the latest stats in our ScoreCentre, and tune in to our live radio coverage.

Galvin hits the turf N By Nick Campton The Magpies have hit the field at Lidcombe Oval, a modest reception for Galvin as runs out. Wests kick off, Eels receive and we're underway! Galvin confirmed for Magpies N By Nick Campton After the news broke yesterday that Galvin's team sent the Tigers a legal letter alleging the 19-year old was being bullied there was a bit of speculation he might not play reserve grade today. But he will take the field - final teams were confirmed about 30 minutes ago and Galvin was in the side. He will play for the Magpies today. Hello, welcome to the NRL blog for Easter Monday! N By Nick Campton Hello everyone, it's Easter Monday, the sun is shining and there's footy on, where else would you rather be than the ABC's live blog? We'll be bringing two games to you today - first up, we'll be taking you through the NSW Cup game between Wests and Parramatta, where Lachlan Galvin will be playing after his contract dramas from the last week. That kicks off at midday, then we'll have the NRL match between the Tigers and Eels from 4pm. Gonna be a good one! Let's have some fun.

title: US defense secretary reportedly shared Yemen attack details with family
text:
US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth reportedly shared details of a March attack on Yemen's Iran-aligned Houthis with his wife, brother and personal lawyers, a month after revelations a US magazine editor was accidentally added to defence group chats.

The New York Times, which broke the story, cited four sources familiar with the message group who said that second chat included details of the schedule of the air strikes.

According to the report, the trio received the same details that were revealed last month by a US magazine editor who was accidentally included in a group chat that contained US President Donald Trump's national security team.

Mr Hegseth's brother Phil and his lawyer Tim Parlatore both have jobs in the Pentagon though their titles vary.

Mr Hegseth's brother is a senior adviser to the secretary for the Department of Homeland Security and a liaison officer in the Defense Department while Mr Parlatore's Linkedin's account says he is a US Navy Reserve commander at the Secretary of Defense office.

Top Pete Hegseth adviser put on leave in Pentagon leak probe Photo shows Pete Hegseth, standing above Donald Trump, spread his hands. The man who was named by Pete Hegseth in the Houthi group chat leak as the best staff point of contact for the National Security Council has been placed on administrative leave.

The reports about the second chat were separately confirmed by CNN, which said the leaks had created concern about the secretary's judgement — including from his former press secretary John Ullyot.

“It’s been a month of total chaos at the Pentagon," Mr Ullyot said in a statement obtained by CNN.

"From leaks of sensitive operational plans to mass firings, the dysfunction is now a major distraction for the president — who deserves better from his senior leadership."

The Atlantic's editor-in-chief, Jeffrey Goldberg, said he was added to a chat on the Signal messaging app on March 13.

A day after Goldberg was added, the group began sharing information about plans for a military operation against the Iran-aligned Houthi rebel group.

A Signal app message from Pete Hegseth shared by The Atlantic editor. (ABC)

Meanwhile, Mr Hegseth's wife Jennifer, a former Fox News producer, has attended sensitive meetings with foreign military counterparts, the Wall Street Journal has reported.

Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer responded to the revelations, saying Mr Hegseth "must be fired".

"The details keep coming out," he wrote on X.

" We keep learning how Pete Hegseth put lives at risk. But Trump is still too weak to fire him. "

The news came after one of Mr Hegseth's leading advisers, Dan Caldwell, was escorted from the Pentagon after being identified during an investigation into leaks at the US Department of Defense.

Mr Caldwell was placed on administrative leave for "an unauthorised disclosure", a US official told Reuters last week.

Following Mr Caldwell's departure, Mr Hegseth's deputy chief of staff Darin Selnick was also put on administrative leave, officials said.

The Pentagon was not immediately available for comment for Reuters.

Reuters/ABC

title: Voters demand clear answers on controversial energy projects
text:
Two contentious energy projects pitched by major parties for WA's South West have managed to cut through voters' malaise during a dual-election year.

Labor's offshore wind farm near Bunbury and the Coalition's proposed nuclear reactor in Collie are novel forms of energy for Australia.

Both projects have incensed some local voters in the Liberal-held federal seats of Forrest and O'Connor, and galvanised large community campaigns since being announced in the area last year.

Protesters gathered near the federal Energy Minister's press conference in Bunbury where he announced the approved offshore wind zone. (ABC South West: Bridget McArthur)

The major parties have gone somewhat quiet on their respective development plans during the federal election campaign thus far.

Meanwhile, the communities at the centre of these energy projects have been ramping up calls for more detail and demanding local candidates reveal where they stand.

Nuclear top of mind for region

The Coalition's nuclear energy policy has been a hot topic in the seat of O'Connor since Collie's retiring coal-fired power station was announced as one of seven proposed reactor sites.

Peter Dutton walks past protesters to his waiting car in Collie. (ABC South West: Bridget McArthur)

Georgia Dowdell had just bought her and her young daughter's "forever home" down the road from the power plant when she heard the news.

She said the policy was a "huge concern" and would be on the minds of many Collie voters come May 3.

"I've always kind of stayed out of [politics] but now it's in my backyard … I'll most definitely be voting against it," Ms Dowdell said.

Georgia Dowdell is concerned a Coalition government would mean a nuclear reactor on her doorstep. (ABC South West: Bridget McArthur)

Fellow Collie resident Brian Kippin said he was in favour of the Coalition's plan, believing it filled an impending gap in baseload power and jobs, but acknowledged others had concerns.

"There are many people who are more supportive of renewables, but when you explain things, it opens their eyes up," he said.

About 100 kilometres down the road in Bridgetown, John Manera said the nuclear policy had him rethinking his typically Liberal vote.

He said he was not opposed to nuclear energy, but he felt the plan was too expensive and lacked detail.

"Even though I've got a lot of reservations about Labor, I think they've probably got the better ideas as far as energy," Mr Manera said.

Liberals fear nuclear could cost votes

A number of prominent Liberal voices have spoken out against the Coalition's nuclear plan, including former party leaders Malcolm Turnbull and John Hewson.

Former Liberal candidate for the Tasmanian seat of Clarke (now Denison) Andrew Gregson said the policy was a death sentence for the party.

He has been advocating for it to be scrapped under the banner of the new advocacy group, Liberals Against Nuclear.

Peter Dutton brought up nuclear twice in this year's budget reply speech. (ABC News: Ian Cutmore)

"We're still very hopeful that the Liberal Party leadership recognise that their nuclear policy is toxic," Mr Gregson said.

New data from the ABC's Vote Compass survey found about 47 per cent of more than 270,000 respondents disagreed with building nuclear power plants, while 38 per cent were supportive.

Undecided voters were more likely to disagree.

John Curtin Institute of Public Policy executive director John Phillimore said the fact Opposition Leader Peter Dutton had not brought up nuclear much in recent weeks could indicate an awareness it was not his party's most popular policy.

John Phillimore says energy will be a key voter issue for the federal seats of O'Connor and Forrest. (ABC News: Courtney Withers)

Mr Dutton only mentioned nuclear twice in his latest budget reply speech — his first since the nuclear policy was announced — compared to eight times in his 2024 budget reply.

On a recent visit to Bunbury, federal Shadow Treasurer Angus Taylor said his party wasn't backing away from the policy.

"I'm happy to say it. Nuclear is incredibly important," he said.

"Zero emission, baseload nuclear generators are going to be central to making sure that we have a future for industry in this country."

Angus Taylor (left) with Liberal Forrest candidate Ben Small in Bunbury last week. (ABC News: Bridget McArthur)

Offshore wind swaying votes

In the seat of Forrest, which covers most of the south-west coastline, Labor's 4,000-square-kilometre offshore wind project has rallied a strident protest group concerned about impacts to the marine ecosystem and recreational fishing.

The group's Facebook page has grown to more than 6,000 people, representing a small but vocal minority of about 110,000 local electors.

To campaigners' delight, Mr Dutton has promised to scrap the project, and locals are pursuing similar commitments from other candidates.

Peter Dutton visited Busselton last year to announce the Liberals would axe Labor's WA offshore wind project if elected. (ABC South West: Bridget McArthur)

At a recent candidate forum in Busselton, audience members started heckling independent candidate Sue Chapman to decide "yes or no".

Ms Chapman chose to remain neutral, saying she would "assess it based on the evidence and aim to bring the community along".

Sue Chapman faces voters at a forum in Busselton. (ABC South West: Bridget McArthur)

Leading the heckling was swinging voter and Busselton resident Mariah Goria, who said she could not vote for anyone supportive of the offshore wind proposal.

"If anyone goes ahead with offshore wind, they're going ahead with ignoring the community," Ms Goria said.

Liberal candidate for Forrest Ben Small has been quick to leverage the issue, attacking Labor and the Greens candidates for their support, and Ms Chapman for fence-sitting.

Ben Small's opposition to offshore wind is the first thing visitors to his web page see. (Supplied: Ben Small)

Have Your Say: What matters to you this federal election? Photo shows A graphic showing a range of reader comments about potential issues in Australia's 2025 federal election. What do you need to know before you vote in the upcoming federal election? What would you ask the candidates? Have Your Say.

Labor candidate Tabitha Dowding has stood by the project, which she said was a great initiative that would create thousands of jobs, and maintained it had a social licence.

Both major parties have thrown barbs at each other's energy policy, often with similar criticisms — unpopular, unproven, expensive.

Meanwhile, Professor Phillimore said minor parties and independents were lining up to collect lost votes.

O'Connor and Forrest have both historically been safe Liberal seats, but with margins shrinking in recent years, Professor Phillimore said neither was as "rusted on" as some presume.

Do you have a story you want to share with the ABC? Contact Bridget McArthur at bridgetmcarthurtips@proton.me. If you're sharing sensitive information, read our tips on how to contact us confidentially.

title: Rune asks 'What did Novak do?' as he ends Alcaraz's unbeaten run
text:
Holger Rune has stunned home-crowd favourite Carlos Alcaraz in straight sets to win the Barcelona Open for his first title since 2023.

Rune defeated the Spaniard 7-6(6), 6-2 for his first title since winning in Munich two years ago, his fifth overall, and his first ATP 500 title.

"It means the world," Rune said. "It was such a great match.

"In the beginning, I was a little bit stressed, because Carlos obviously plays big-time tennis. I had to breathe a lot and find my rhythm.

"After he broke me, I got more into the match and played my tennis. The first set was a big battle, it was super important to win it and gain the momentum. I'm so proud of myself."

Alcaraz was coming off a nine-match winning streak that included his first Monte Carlo Masters title last weekend.

ABC Elite Athletes in Australian Women's Sport Survey: We want to hear from you Photo shows A stylised graphic with three silhouettes of unidentified a female footballer, tennis player, basketballer ABC Sport and Deakin University have partnered to produce the first ABC Elite Athletes in Australian Women’s Sport Survey.

That title in Monaco was part of a brilliant run on clay dating back to Alcaraz's run to the French Open crown last year, with the Spaniard winning 21 of his past 22 matches on the surface leading into the Barcelona final.

The only match he lost during that streak was the epic Paris Olympics final at Roland Garros against Novak Djokovic. Rune said he looked to the Serb for inspiration.

"I told myself, 'What did Novak do when he beat him?'" he said.

"I kind of played it in my mind, the Olympic final. I was watching when they played. Amazing match. I thought to myself, 'OK, let's try to play that kind of style,' really make him play a lot of balls.

"I'm very happy [with] how I stayed composed when it really mattered. I was also very brave when it mattered."

Alcaraz was searching for his third title of the year and 19th of his career. He won the Barcelona Open in 2022 and 2023 but missed last year, meaning he was on a 14-match winning streak at the tournament, including two wins over Australian number one Alex de Minaur.

Rune, who left in tears after finishing runner-up to Jack Draper at Indian Wells in March, rallied from a break down in the opening set and converted his fourth set point before cruising through the second set against Alcaraz, who twice needed treatment on his upper right leg.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

It was the first ATP tour-level final between two players aged 21 or younger since 2022.

"We've been playing each other since [we were] 12 years old. Time flies," Alcaraz told his fellow 21-year-old.

"I'm really happy to see us in this position, how far we've [come]. Keep going."

Alcaraz will lose his world-number-two ranking to Alexander Zverev, who won his third Munich title with a comprehensive 6-2, 6-4 victory over American Ben Shelton.

Rune will return to the top 10 for the first time in over a year, moving up to number nine as the clay-court season continues with the Madrid Open this week.

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

AP/ABC

title: Faced with extremes, the Spinifex People are being pushed to the limit
text:
Lennard Walker's eyes widen as he recalls the roaring desert rain.

Last year the Spinifex elder, who was born in the Great Victoria Desert, spent four days stranded on a dirt track in one of the most remote parts of the country.

Alongside him was Noli Rictor, who lived a traditional nomadic life in the bush with his family until 1986, the last known Australians to do so.

The party of seven had set out from Kalgoorlie, 600 kilometres east of Perth, for their homes at Tjuntjuntjara (pronounced joon-joon-jara), a 10-hour drive further east.

Tjuntjuntjara is one of Australia's most remote communities. (ABC: Sharon Gordon)

Despite their deep knowledge of the country, they were shocked at the downpour.

"Big rain," Mr Walker says, arms extended towards the sky.

"Really big rain.

"Stuck halfway."

When they were finally rescued by a helicopter, the community breathed a sigh of relief.

Lennard Walker is a senior Pitjantjatjara law man. (ABC Esperance: Emily Smith)

But their troubles were only just beginning.

The washed-out roads between Kalgoorlie and Tjuntjuntjara would remain closed for six months.

The only other access route, which takes 14 hours to travel from Ceduna, would often leave food delivery trucks bogged — five once became stranded in a single day — or needing thousands of dollars' worth of repairs.

Loading...

The Anangu, or Spinifex People, are famous for their resilience, surviving atomic testing and the missionary era to return to their homelands in the 1980s.

But Jon Lark, chief executive of the Paupiyala Tjarutja Aboriginal Corporation (PTAC), which manages Tjuntjuntjara on behalf of the Spinifex People, says current pressures are pushing the community to its limit.

Lennard Walker and his party were stranded in WA's flooded outback. (Supplied: Jon Lark)

Returning to country

Tjuntjuntjara was born of a dream from its old people, desperate to return to their country after years of displacement.

White settlers had built missions, launched rockets and, from 1953, tested nuclear weapons at Maralinga and Emu Field within range of their land.

Spinifex elder Ned Grant, who spent his early years crisscrossing the desert country of Western Australia's interior before ending up at Cundeelee Mission, was part of the homelands movement.

Ned Grant is a senior elder who helped lead the return to country. (ABC Goldfields: Katrina Tap)

When the mission closed, and the state government bought a cattle station called Coonana, thinking former residents would run it, they seized the opportunity to return.

"[Tjuntjuntjara] is closer to home, where he grew up, Spinifex country," Tjuntjuntjara resident Donna Marie Brown said, translating Mr Grant's Pitjantjatjara.

In 2000 the Spinifex People became the first in Western Australia to achieve native title, using artworks to demonstrate their 25,000-year-old connection to country.

Yet 25 years on, profound challenges remain.

Tjuntjuntjara remains home to elders who led the return to country in the 1980s. (ABC Esperance: Emily Smith)

'I can't have a shower'

Shona Jamieson's kitchen, toilet and shower have been blocked for months.

The Tjuntjuntjara woman has long been proud of her independence, working numerous jobs and living alone with her dogs.

Shona Jamieson must go to neighbours' houses to access a shower and toilet. (ABC Esperance: Emily Smith)

But she has no option but to rely on others for basic facilities.

"I can't have a shower, I can't go toilet. I can't cook something in the kitchen," she said.

The WA Department of Communities is arranging for a plumber to visit.

Jon Lark believes Tjuntjuntjara needs far more support. (ABC Goldfields: Jarrod Lucas)

The community faces similar hurdles with air conditioning.

In January, Tjuntjuntjara sweltered through 19 days above 40 degrees Celsius.

Mr Lark, who has worked with the Spinifex at different times since 1987, estimated about a third of houses had no functioning air conditioning and others were cut off when pre-paid power expired.

He said the hot, overcrowded houses put elderly, ill residents at risk and could lead to broader social problems.

But among the services Tjuntjuntjara lacks is local police.

Tjuntjuntjara is 700 kilometres north-east of Kalgoorlie. (Supplied)

"There are increasing social issues … about substance abuse and domestic violence and safety," Mr Lark said.

" And what the people see as an answer is a greater police presence. "

A WA Police spokesperson did not comment on resourcing, but said it flew personnel to the community in emergencies.

Mr Lark said while police had once visited every six weeks, their schedule was interrupted by last year's floods.

He worried that extreme weather would continue to make all kinds of service delivery more challenging.

Food security is a massive challenge for the people of Tjuntjuntjara. (ABC Esperance: Emily Smith)

'We need a big one'

Food was flown in twice at the state government's expense when roads were out of action last year.

But the community's 30-year-old shop, with a tin shed for storage, could only hold a small amount in reserve.

Local resident Lawrence Minning said they needed more space.

Lawrence Minning wants a bigger store in Tjuntjuntjara. (ABC Esperance: Emily Smith)

"It's too small," he said. "We need a big one.

" [And it's] too dear, going up. They should drop [prices] down. "

When the ABC visited earlier this month, a small can of tuna was $5.30, two litres of cordial was $8.49, and a four-pack of pies was $14.99 — compared to $2.70, $4.40 and $9 for the same products at a major supermarket.

Food prices are much higher in Tjuntjuntjara than most parts of Australia. (ABC Esperance: Emily Smith)

"The shop is dear," Anangu woman Ms Brown said, with Mr Grant nodding in agreement.

" You've got to go in with $300 or $250 to buy a lot of food. "

Mr Lark said the extreme freight and fuel costs required to get food to Tjuntjuntjara — via Alice Springs, Adelaide and Ceduna — added to the high prices.

Every fortnight, workers rally to unload the food truck. (ABC Esperance: Emily Smith)

Last year locals worried food and fuel trucks might stop running altogether because the delivery route was so treacherous.

Following crisis meetings, Main Roads WA committed $6 million to improve roads to both Kalgoorlie and South Australia.

The work is expected to occur later this year.

The Department of Fire and Emergency Services (DFES) said it might reimburse agencies for flood damage repairs along the road to Kalgoorlie, but said the road to South Australia was not government owned or managed and therefore was ineligible.

Mr Lark said he worried the roads would remain just as vulnerable to future extreme weather events.

Acclaimed artist Timo Hogan fixes a car on the road to Tjuntjuntjara. (ABC Esperance: Emily Smith)

Federal party promises

Federal Labor said it would subsidise 30 key products at many remote community stores from July, as part of its 10-year strategy to improve food security.

"We know that remote First Nations communities are vulnerable to extreme weather conditions, making them disproportionately impacted by food insecurity," a spokesperson said.

They also invited PTAC to apply for a Local Investments Funding grant to improve roads.

Workers unload the fortnightly grocery delivery. (ABC Esperance: Emily Smith)

But a Coalition spokesperson said the food security strategy lacked detail.

If elected, they vowed the Coalition would reduce cost-of-living pressures by halving the fuel excise and offering cheaper energy.

They said the Regional Australia Future Fund would ensure money was available for fixing roads and improving supply routes.

Mr Lark said he hoped to meet with newly elected federal government representatives after next month's vote.

The WA government has set aside $6m to upgrade Tjuntjuntjara's access roads. (Supplied/ABC: Katrina Tap)

'Watch this space'

Despite its challenges, many locals would never leave Tjuntjuntjara.

"The old people were absolutely adamant to return to this place," Mr Lark said.

" And they're adamant they're going to stay. "

People love spending time in the bush surrounding Tjuntjuntjara. (ABC Goldfields: Katrina Tap)

He said although younger residents went away to boarding school, many had returned.

The community is known throughout the central desert for the strength of its culture, with people regularly heading out bush for hunting, ranger work and cultural business.

Its artists are internationally acclaimed, with Noli Rictor winning the top award at the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Art Awards last year, and fellow local Timo Hogan winning it three years earlier.

Noli Rictor with his winning painting (left); Patju Presely painting a large canvas. (Supplied: Olivia Sproull/Amanda Dent)

Another elder, Patju Presley, has a three-metre painting in the Australian embassy in Washington DC, and the WA Museum has showcased a major Spinifex Arts Project exhibition for months.

"Pukulpa," Mr Grant said, describing his Tjuntjuntjara life.

"It means he's happy," Ms Brown translated.

"He's on country, you know."

Tjuntjuntjara residents regularly spend time on country. (ABC Goldfields: Katrina Tap)

But Mr Lark said unless support from all tiers of government improved, the Spinifex People would suffer, due to the challenges of remaining in community or the fresh ones that came with leaving.

"People's experience of going to live in metropolitan areas and regional towns isn't always a positive improvement, so I guess it's just watch this space.

"We can only hope that the … plans that we're implementing are going to have success."

title: The travel toll of living with endometriosis in regional Australia
text:
Driving 450 kilometres multiple times a month to access gynaecological care is the reality for many women living with chronic health conditions in regional Australia.

It's something 18-year-old Mount Gambier woman Lucy Savage has done every two weeks since being diagnosed with endometriosis, adenomyosis and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) last year.

She says the frequent travel for care is unsustainable and has impacted her family and future.

" I am in my gap year but I can't work full time … I work three days a week partly because of the travel [to Adelaide] and partly because of the pain I am in. "

Lucy Savage gave evidence at a parliamentary inquiry into endometriosis last year. (Supplied: Lucy Savage)

The money Ms Savage has been able to save has gone back into funding her travel and medical appointments.

"My boyfriend is studying in Adelaide so I stay with him, but my parents work full time, they can't afford to drive down or travel with me," she said.

Her experience is not rare, nor are her circumstances.

Travel an 'emotional and physical' toll

It is estimated that one in seven women in Australia have endometriosis.

The Yorke Peninsula Pelvic Pain Clinic at Kadina was the first of 22 clinics in Australia to open in 2023 following the Albanese government's $58.3 million package for endometriosis and pelvic pain in the 2022-23 budget.

The centres were introduced in every state and territory and established in existing GP clinics, with each service receiving $700,000 over four years to provide multidisciplinary care.

GP and director of the Kadina clinic Anna Kearney said more than 235 women from across South Australia had accessed the service since it opened.

"They travel from as far north as Roxby Downs to as far south as the Adelaide Hills," she said.

" It's been so difficult and so painful, both emotionally and physically for these women, and a lot of the time the first half an hour is me just listening and acknowledging that it's been a bit of a shitshow. "

Anna Kearney says there is a two- to four-month waitlist at the Kadina clinic. (Supplied: Anna Kearney)

Dr Kearney said the strain travel put on women living regionally and the lack of access to services was not spoken about enough.

"If someone wants to see a gynaecologist and you've got kids, a job, adding that distance can make it a complete nightmare," she said.

" Endometriosis doesn't discriminate based on your geographical location; just because you live in the regions, it doesn't mean you don't need these services. "

Private practitioners the backbone to regions

In the Riverland, Elizabeth Eske owns and operates the region's only women's pelvic health physiotherapy clinic.

She contributed to the South Australian Parliamentary Select Committee into endometriosis at a hearing in Berri last year, and expressed her concern for the lack of services and practitioners in the Riverland.

Ms Eske said without her private practice there would be no multidisciplinary care in the north-east of the state from the Victorian border to Adelaide.

Ms Eske has the only specialised clinic in the Riverland region. (Supplied: Bec Shaw Photography)

"There are no women's health physiotherapists working for SA Health in the Riverland, so for these women there's no access to those services via the state health system."

She said women were eligible for five private physiotherapy sessions under Medicare over a 12-month period, with a rebate of $60.35.

"In the scheme of things, women need a lot more than that."

For Ms Savage, she had already used her five sessions by the start of April.

Endometriosis quiz: How much do we know about the disease? Photo shows A woman in a yellow top and teens clutches her stomach on a couch How much do you know about endometriosis?

Inquiry welcomed but future uncertain

After a year of taking submissions and hearing from witnesses, the parliamentary committee handed down its report in March with 20 recommendations.

SA Health said it had accepted the recommendations "in principle".

Ms Eske said she would have liked to see more support for regional private practitioners who were often the only healthcare providers in communities.

"I see women as young as 19 coming in but they might not get a diagnosis until they're 26," she said.

"If we get women in earlier … we can get them the management plan they need sooner."

The federal government in its 2025 budget announced a three-year expansion of the endometriosis and pelvic pain clinics if re-elected, with an additional 11 clinics to be introduced.

Minister for Health and Aged Care Mark Butler did not state where the new clinics would be located, but said they "would be established within Primary Health Networks that do not currently have a clinic operating".

Lucy Savage's experience is not rare, nor are her circumstances. (ABC South East SA: Conor Burke)

Lucy Savage hopes one of the clinics will be closer to home so she can start saving for her future.

"A lot of the time people assume you could do [appointments] over Zoom, but endometriosis is such a personal and individual condition, you need to be there in person," she said.

" Awareness and education around endometriosis has skyrocketed in recent years, but it's still got a long way to go. "

title: Boothby is a relatively wealthy electorate, but voters still worry about the cost of living
text:
About a year ago, Matthew Perovic had to find a housemate to share the cost of his rental in Adelaide's inner-southern suburbs.

He has lived in the property for about nine years, and for the first seven there was only one rental increase of $20 a week.

"Then it went up $100 week," Mr Perovic said.

Other than partners, it was the first time he had to have a housemate in at least 15 years.

Despite having a higher salary now, he is worried about the cost of living.

"I've found that it's not just things costing more in general, but I'm being left with less money left over each pay cycle," he said.

"And not really being able to explain why, when my activities and food (consumption) has stayed the same."

Mr Perovic's home is in the seat of Boothby, one of South Australia's two marginal electorates.

"I know everyone's vote is equal, but when it's a swing seat, it does feel a bit more important," he said.

Cost-of-living 'dread'

The ABC has received thousands of submissions from its "Your Say" campaign, gathering the thoughts and concerns of people across the country in the lead-up to the federal election.

According to ABS data, the median weekly household income in the marginal seat of Boothby is $1,643 compared to the state average of $1,455.

Despite this, voters in the seat said cost of living and housing were two major concerns.

"I gave up on thinking about buying a house a long time ago," Mr Perovic said.

"Every time you'd get close, everything would be out of reach."

Mr Perovic also finds himself discussing financial pressures with friends, family and his new housemate often.

"Even going to the shops together, we'll just be like 'is that seriously what that costs now?'," he said.

"I've never had to dread going to fill up [on petrol] before or when you want to use the air conditioner.

"We'll just talk and joke about things like that."

Matthew Perovic and his housemate Daniel often talk about the cost-of-living. (ABC News: Sarah Maunder)

For him, none of the policies from any of the major parties have really caught his attention.

"You see all the quick fixes, of dropping fuel prices or a quick boost of cash, and it's like … that's all well and good to do, but it's not something long-term that will fix the problem," he said.

"It's almost just ... a bandage on the problem."

Housing 'completely unaffordable' for kids

Boothby resident David Schilling is the father of six kids aged between 17 and 28.

Like Matthew Perovic, he also made a submission to the ABC's "Your Say" campaign.

The Party Room Photo shows An orange background with graphics and words reading The Party Room with Kelly and Karvelas with the ABC LIsten app logo. What's really going on in parliament house? Patricia Karvelas and Fran Kelly deep dive into the week's biggest political stories and answer listener questions. Stream The Party Room on ABC listen.

He identified housing, the environment and the rising cost of living as some of his biggest concerns this election.

"When I bought my first house, I was 21 and it was in Hobart," Mr Schilling said.

"I bought it for $73,000, which today sounds ridiculous; at that time, my annual income was about $27,000, so it was completely manageable.

"These days [buying a house] is completely unaffordable for most kids."

David Schilling is worried that his kids won’t have the same opportunities that he did as a young person. (ABC News: Sarah Maunder)

Mr Schilling said all of his children had done everything they could to set themselves up for success — but it was still not enough to enter the housing market without help.

"They've studied hard at school, they've all gone to university, some of them have got double degrees, some of them are doing university and TAFE at the same time," he said.

"They're all straddled with quite a significant HECS debt, so on those parameters, it's extremely difficult to save.

"And that's why, of course, five out of the six of them are still living at home."

Local political battle

Labor's Louise Miller-Frost won the seat of Boothby at the 2022 federal election.

She holds the seat on a margin of 3.3 per cent.

Returning former MP — Liberal Nicolle Flint — is contesting the seat this year.

She was first elected in 2016 but retired at the 2022 election, later citing endometriosis as a major factor in her decision.

Labor MP Louise Miller-Frost (left) is trying to hold onto Boothby against Liberal candidate and former MP Nicolle Flint. (ABC News)

David Schilling said he had not paid too much attention to the local candidates.

"So [for me] it's really about the more macro-economic and social policies that they [the two major parties] put forward, it's really nothing about the local politics," he said.

"In terms of housing, and I don't know if this is possible because I am not an economist, it would be great to see if wealth creation can be separated from home ownership.

"Because as I see it, the generational divide of those that own homes and those that are renting has been exacerbated in the last 20 years and it's only getting worse.

"And in terms of what policies the different parties are putting forward, it really feels like it's really short-term solutions for long-term problems."

More cost-of-living concerns in Brighton

Jetty Road, Brighton is a beachside hub within Boothby — not to be confused with Jetty Road, Glenelg, the tourist hotspot just a few kilometres north that also happens to be in Boothby.

Brighton beach, in Adelaide’s southern suburbs, lies within the Boothby electorate. (ABC News: Sarah Maunder)

On a sunny weekday during the school holidays, the Brighton street's cafes and shops are buzzing with people enjoying the warm April day.

The ABC spoke to a handful of people who identified themselves as residents of Boothby about their cost-of-living concerns this election.

"The weekly [grocery] bill has gone up," said Terry Watkins.

"And obviously a lot of the energy bills as well, so yeah, you notice a lot of rises in all of those."

His wife, Jane, said she noticed more people doing their grocery shop with a calculator.

"I do think the increases [in grocery prices] are literally happening weekly, you can tell," she said.

Terry and Jane Watkins live in Boothby. (ABC News: Sarah Maunder)

"I'm not too sure whether either of them [the Liberal and Labor candidates] are thinking about really the normal people that can't afford to live."

Kurt Winter is a Boothby resident who works away for six months of the year.

He said that although the cost of living had not affected him too much, he really noticed the rise in costs when he was back home.

"There's probably a general, slow rise in a lot of prices that people don't sometimes notice but ... when I come back there is a bit of a shock," he said.

Ana Obradovic, 30, doesn't live in Boothby — she is in the neighbouring electorate of Kingston, which is a safe Labor seat held by cabinet minister Amanda Rishworth.

But Ms Obradovic said she was frustrated by the state of housing affordability and availability in Australia.

Kingston voter Ana Obradovic said housing a was a big concern for her. (ABC News: Sarah Maunder)

"I think everybody has a right to own a home, and looking at the housing market, even the rental market right now, prices have almost doubled in some of the places that I was originally hoping to buy," she said.

"Young people, old people, workers, retirees … we're all kind of bearing the brunt of the cost-of-living crisis."
